title: St. Paul's Mission
text:
St. Paul's Mission was a <a href="Society%20of%20Jesus">Jesuit</a> <a href="Mission%20%28Christian%29">mission</a> church established in the <a href="Hudson%27s%20Bay%20Company">Hudson's Bay Company</a>'s (HBC) <a href="Columbia%20District">Columbia District</a>, in the <a href="Pacific%20Northwest">Pacific Northwest</a> region of <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, in the 1830s. The mission was built near the HBC's <a href="Fort%20Colville">Fort Colville</a>, on the bluff then overlooking <a href="Kettle%20Falls">Kettle Falls</a> on the <a href="Columbia%20River">Columbia River</a>. The building still stands today.
History.
Both <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a> and <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> missionaries visited Kettle Falls several times from 1836 on, attempting to convert <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">natives</a> to Christianity.
The first missionaries, representatives of the <a href="American%20Board%20of%20Commissioners%20for%20Foreign%20Missions">American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions</a> and sponsored by the <a href="Presbyterianism">Presbyterians</a> and <a href="Congregational%20church">Congregationalists</a>, arrived in 1836. They were unable to baptize any Indians.
Catholic missionaries, led by French-Canadian Fathers <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Norbert%20Blanchet">François Norbert Blanchet</a> and <a href="Modeste%20Demers">Modeste Demers</a>, arrived in 1838. They delivered the first Catholic mass between the <a href="Rocky%20Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a> and the <a href="Cascade%20Range">Cascade Range</a> in 1839 and baptized 19 Indians, but were unable to establish a permanent mission. Their efforts were more focused on <a href="St.%20Paul%20Roman%20Catholic%20Church%20%28St.%20Paul%2C%20Oregon%29">St. Paul Roman Catholic Church</a>, in the <a href="Willamette%20Valley">Willamette Valley</a>.
Following Belgian <a href="Pierre-Jean%20De%20Smet">Father DeSmet</a>'s preaching to the Sxoielpi (<a href="Colville%20%28tribe%29">Colville Indians</a>) in August 1845, a small log chapel was built. Two years later the present hand-hewn log church replaced it. Sometime around 1869, St. Paul's Mission was abandoned in favor of a location seven miles north of the present city of <a href="Colville%2C%20Washington">Colville</a>. Damaged by fire in 1910, the present structure was restored in 1939–40.
